column3: For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage. It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions-a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference.

column3: The base starts with farmers and slaves. The economical positions rise as they go up. At the very top point of the pyramid are the gods. Here is the order from greatest to least: Egyptian Gods/Pharaohs,  nobles/priests, soldiers, craftmen/traders, and lastly farmers/slaves. The gods are at the highest position in status. They have the right to overpower everyone. Also, since everyone praises them they believe that the gods were responsible of many things as well. Like safety. Sometimes the pharaohs direct the army or create laws. As stated in the text, "They had absolute power over their subjects...The pharaoh directed the army in case of a foreign threat or an internal conflict. All the laws were enacted at the discretion of the pharaoh." Because the pharaohs/gods couldn't do all the duties themselves they have assistants called viziers which are chief ministers. They have the duty of collecting taxes from people like farmers. According to the article, "No single person could manage all these duties without assistance. The pharaoh appointed a chief minister called a vizier as a supervisor. The vizier ensured that taxes were collected." Called a "chain of command" the viziers have assistants as well.  They are called scribes; they are the only ones who can read and write. Now under the whole chain of gods/pharaohs there are the nobles/priests. According to the text, the only people who can develop government posts are the nobles. And priests' duties are to keep the gods satisfied. Like said in the text, "Right below the pharaoh in status were powerful nobles and priests. Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods." Also, the nobles grow very wealthy from recieving all the gifts of the gods from the subjects. Next are the soldiers. The soldiers fight in wars or end "domestic uprisings." Also, they sometimes keep an eye on farmers, peasants, and slaves. As said in the article, "Soldiers fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings. During long periods of peace, soldiers also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves who were involved in building such structures as pyramids and palaces." Next comes the middle class which is made up of skilled people life artisans, craftmen/women, and physicians. The craftmen would create jewlery and other products and then sell them to make some money. They were known as the merchants and sorekeepers. "Skilled workers such as physicians and craftsmen/women made up the middle class. Craftsmen made and sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus products, tools, and other useful things. Naturally, there were people needed to buy goods from artisans and traders. These were the merchants and storekeepers who sold these goods to the public." And at the bottom/base are the farmers and slaves. The farmers has to raise animals, take care of the fields, conduct some tasks in the stone quarries, construct royal monuments, and are responsible to keep the reservoirs and canals in shape. They also have to pay 60% of their annual harvest towards tax. "Farmers tended the fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs  in good order, worked in the stone quarries, and built the royal monuments. Farmers paid taxes that could amount to as much as 60% of their yearly harvest—that’s a lot of hay!"  Although people can't raise their status, young boys can go to school to learn how to read/write and then can become scribes or can apply for employment in the government which would make their status rise. The slaves have to work on developing projects and put extreme effort at the disrection of the nobles or pharaohs. "At the bottom of the social structure were slaves and farmers. Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. In addition to being forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles."
column4: Sure, here is the reworded passage:  The base of the pyramid is composed of farmers and slaves. This position gives rise to the nobility, priesthood, soldiers, craftsmen, traders, and lastly, those who are the farmers and slaves. The gods, who hold the highest position, possess absolute power over their subjects, directing the army, enacting laws, and making sure everything goes according to plan. The nobles and priests follow in status, with priests aiding the gods in fulfilling their duties. The soldiers, the middle class, skilled workers, and artisans occupy various positions that provide goods and services to society. At the lowest level are the farmers and slaves, who are responsible for raising animals, maintaining public infrastructure and completing tasks related to building pyramids and palaces. Furthermore, they are obligated to pay taxes that can be as high as 60% of their annual harvest, a significant amount that reflects the low status they occupy in society.

column3: The Third Wave developed over such a short period of time because the students that joined the movement actively participated in spreading it, exemplified in the passage, "All of the students ... received a special assignment, like designing a Third Wave Banner, stopping non-members from entering the class, or other tasks to bring honor to the movement. Jones instructed the students on how to initiate new members, and by the end of the day the movement had over 200 participants." (CommonLit Staff 3) In essence, a sort of pyramid scheme was formed: groups of students that joined the movement actively encouraged other students to join, and these newly added students encouraged even more students to join; the cycle would continue. The experiment was ended because, "... the students became increasingly involved in the project and their discipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that Jones felt it was slipping out of control. He decided to terminate the movement ..." (CommonLit Staff 4) I think that this passage is relatively self-explanatory; Jones simply felt it was becoming out-of-control and wanted to end the experiment and to that it was an experiment to the students.
column4: The Third Wave emerged quickly due to the active engagement of its participants. Students actively spread the movement through various means, including design competitions and other tasks. As a result, the movement grew rapidly, with over 200 participants by the final day.  This experiment demonstrates the potential for rapid growth when a group of motivated individuals actively collaborates to achieve a shared goal. However, the researchers found that as the movement gained momentum, its members' commitment and discipline began to decline. Ultimately, the project was terminated due to the participants' increasing involvement and the potential for misuse.

column3: Here is how the structure of the ancient Egyptian system of government works. To start off, at the top were the gods, like Ra, Osiris, and Isis stated on paragraph 1. Pharaoh's were the next and egyptians believed Pharaoh's were gods but in human forms and they had absolute power over their subjects which is stated on paragraph 2. The pharaoh directed an army  in case of a foreign threat or an internal conflict stated on paragraph 3. All laws were enacted at the discretion of the pharaoh. Each farmer paid taxes in the form of grains, which were stored in the pharaoh's warehouses. This grain was used to feed the people in the event of a famine stated on paragraph 3.  The pharaoh appointed a cheif minister called a vizier as a supervisor. The vizier ensured that taxes were collected stated on paragraph 4. Working with the vizier were scribes who kept government records. These high-level employess had mastered a rare skill in ancient Egypt, they could read and write stated on paragraph 5. Below pharaoh's were nobles and priests. Only nobles could hold government posts, which in these positions they profited from tributes, paid to the pharaoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods stated on paragraph 6. Soliders fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings. During long periods of peace, soilders also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves who were involved in building structures like pyramids and palaces stated on paragraph 8. Skilled workers like physicians and craftsmen/women made up the middle class. Craftsmen made and sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus, products, tools, and other useful things stated on paragraph 9.  There were people that needed to buy goods from artisians and traders. These were the merchants and storekeepers who sold these goods to the public stated on paragraph 10.  At the bottom of the social structure were the slaves and farmers. Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. Being forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles stated on paragraph 11. Farmers tended the fields. raised animals, kept canals, and reservoirs in good order, worked in stone quarries, and built the royal monuments. Farmers paid taxes that could do as much as 60% of their yearly harvest stated on paragraph 12. Social mobility was not impossible. A small number of peasants and farmers moved up the economic ladder. Families saved money to send their sons to village schools to learn trades.  These schools were run by priests or by artisans. Boys who learned to read and write could become scribes, then go on a gain employment in the government stated on paragraph 13.  That is how the system of Ancient Egypt worked.
column4: Sure, here is a rewritten version of the passage with a similar number of words and writing ability level:  The ancient Egyptian government had a strong hierarchical structure with distinct roles and responsibilities. The pharaoh held absolute power as the supreme authority. His decrees were followed by the nobility and priests who acted as intermediaries between the pharaoh and the people. The farmers were responsible for tending the fields and providing for the population. Skilled artisans and craftsmen played a vital role in the society, creating objects used in daily life and for special occasions.  The government officials were appointed by the pharaoh and held positions such as vizier and scribes, responsible for collecting taxes and maintaining government records, respectively. They were highly trained individuals, skilled in reading and writing, essential skills in ancient Egypt. The lower echelons of society were occupied by slaves and farmers, with the latter playing a crucial role in maintaining agricultural production.  Social mobility was accessible to some, as a few peasants and farmers had the opportunity to rise to higher economic levels through education and trade. Families could save money to send their sons to village schools, where they learned trades and became skilled artisans or scribes, contributing to the growth of the government.

The pharaohs, governed the land from the top of a social pyramid. Below them were government officials, followed by priests, scribes, artisans, and peasants. Some peasants and farmers climbed the ladder by saving money and sending their sons to village schools to learn trades. These schools were often overseen by priests or artisans. Boys who excelled in either literacy or numeracy could pursue careers within the government, where they held positions of influence and authority."

column3: In the novle "the jungle" by Upton Sinclair he describes how the meat packing industery worked with the meat. He went on to describe in detail the horriable unsafe, disgusting, and moraliy wrong prosses that of which the meat was packaged. One thing the industery would do is putting many chemicals into the rotten meat to make it look better so that people would buy it.  As seen in the novel, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell [...] also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. In the pickling of hams they had an ingenious apparatus, by which they saved time and increased the capacity of the plant—a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. [...]  Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as “Number Three Grade,” but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron."(Sinclair 2). This qoute shows how the industery would use jsut about any means to sell the meat they had even if it ment using unsafe means to change it completly. Such as droping loads of rotten meat into tubs of vinager and leaving it so that it would be more appealing.  In "The Jungle" it also states, "Some of it they would make into "smoked" sausage – but as the smoking took time, and was therefore expensive, they would call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown." (Sinclair 5). This qoute shows one of the many dangerous chemicals they would put in the meat, as borax is a cleaning tool. Eatting could lead to death as seen in www.medicalnewstoday.com it states, "Borax is not safe to ingest. According to the NLM's Toxicology Data Network, borax is easy for the body to break down when either inhaled or swallowed. However, if inhalation or ingestion occurs, both serious poisoning and organ damage can result."(Wilson 2019). This quote shows how dangerous it is to ingest Borax.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage with a similar number of words and writing ability level:  In the novel "The Jungle", Upton Sinclair describes the meatpacking industry's gruesome and inhumane practices. He exposes the unethical methods used by the industry to make cheap and misleading food. One common trick used by the industry was to add chemicals to rotten meat to disguise its appearance and disguise the smell. Sinclair also details the shocking methods used to preserve meat, such as using borax or other chemicals to bleach and color the meat. These practices were not only cruel but also unsafe. They posed a significant threat to public health and were often linked to outbreaks of foodborne illness.

column3: This factory would mix spoiled meat with normal meat "It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference. " Along with this, the factory would "pickle" the meat if it was spoiled to completely remove the foul odor. "there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor—a process known to the workers as “giving them thirty per cent."
column4: The factory combined spoiled meat with other meat on a massive scale, with no distinct odor detectable within the final product. The facility resorted to two distinct methods to eliminate the smell: salting and pickling. During the salting process, the meat was exposed to high-temperature treatments to remove any remaining odor. Following the salting process, the meat was subject to a pickling process that annihilated the odor completely. This process involved intentionally adding a significant amount of salt to the meat, thereby destroying the cells responsible for the unpleasant odor.

column4: The social structure in Egypt served as a framework that guided how citizens were valued based on their accomplishments. The pyramid-shaped structure consisted of three distinct levels. The upper tier housed high-ranking officials, while the middle class was comprised of individuals in various skilled professions, including carpenters, merchants, and artisans. The lowest tier was occupied by slaves, who were considered the lowest valued segment of society and performed essential tasks such as construction and maintenance.

column3: They used many wild methods of masking the smell and overall evidence of spoiled meat. First they'd pickle them, then rub it in baking(?) soda so it wouldn't smell, as seen in the 2nd paragraph, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." and they'd also stick a needle which could inject the meat with pickle. " In the pickling of hams they had an ingenious apparatus, by which they saved time and increased the capacity of the plant—a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds." paragraph 2.
column4: They employed unorthodox methods to conceal the smell of spoiled meat. Initially, they soaked the meat in pickling brine to mask any unpleasant odors. Jonas explained that they would rub the soaked meat with baking soda to combat the aforementioned smell, similar to the method employed by the salesman, who sold the treated food without disclosing its hidden ingredients. The tactic involved injecting a needle with pickling brine into the meat, creating an immediate and efficient way to remove the unpleasant odor. In the context of hams, they developed an ingenious apparatus involving a hollow needle fed through the meat for quick and efficient pickling.

column3: The factory used all of the spoiled meat no matter what the circumstances were.  For example, they would fill spoiled hams with a pickling filler that covered up the fact that they were spoiled.  In addition, people would collect all of the scraps and spoiled meat on the ground.  They put the dead rats, poisoned bread, and the rat poop into the same cart.  They would dump these carts into barrels.  One time a year they would dump these barrels into the same system with "fresh" meat.  In a sense, no matter how spoiled the meat was, they would never throw it away.  All of the spoiled meat was dumped into with new meat.  Spoiled meat was sold just like new meat.

At the bottom of this social hierarchy were the slaves and the farmers, whose hard work ensured that the civilization continued to thrive.

column3: The Third Wave experiment was a huge success in showing the young generations on how people followed the crowd, even if it was unethical. This event was conducted by Mr. Jones a history teacher, which was surprised by the number of students joined in on the experiment. This event caught on because it was more normal to participate then not to. You were looked at as weird and wrong for not joining in. The students even started reporting each other for not doing their specific duties. "Jones was surprised that some of the students started reporting to him when other members of the movement failed to abide by the rules." paragraph 3. The students saw huge improvements in their grades and felt impowered, so there only a benefit for them. The experiment ended by Jones called the members to a rally. Jones stated that the president was announcing the national use of the program. "He decided to terminate the movement, so he lied to students by announcing that the Third Wave was a part of a nationwide movement and that on the next day a presidential candidate of the movement would publicly announce its existence on television." paragraph 4. He presented them a blank TV to snap them out of the Nazi mindset. Overall, the project was very effective in teaching the students.
column4: The Third Wave experiment demonstrated the profound influence of peer pressure on young generations. Mr. Jones, a history teacher, unexpectedly witnessed a significant number of students participating in the experiment. This spontaneous emergence stemmed from its novelty and normalcy surrounding participation, reinforcing the notion that following the crowd could be an acceptable behavior in some situations.  Participants' grades significantly increased after the Third Wave experiment, signifying empowerment and a sense of belonging. However, the experiment's conclusion with an abrupt cancellation by Mr. Jones triggered resistance from the students. Despite their initial enthusiasm, some individuals reported noncompliance, demonstrating a potential disconnect between the individual's internal beliefs and their actual participation behavior.  Finally, the Third Wave experiment served as a significant teaching tool, effectively communicating the detrimental effects of adhering to rigid societal norms.

column3: At the  top of the Egyptian government system was the pharaoh, he was in control of everything  and was believed to be a god in human form."Their leaders, called pharaohs, were believed to be gods in human form."  The pharaoh would appoint a vizier as a supervisor,  his job was to ensured taxes were collected."The pharaoh appointed a chief minister called a vizier as a supervisor. The vizier ensured that taxes were collected." Right below the pharaoh was the nobles and priests. Nobles would hold places in the Egyptian government. "Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh" Priests job was the please the gods." Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods."  Next were soldiers, their jobs were to fight in wars or quelled domestic uprisings, also look over the peasants, farmers, and slaves."Soldiers fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings...soldiers also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves" At the bottom of the government were slaves and farmers. Farmers tended to the fields, raising animals,  and kept canals and reservoirs."Farmers tended the fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs in good order, worked in the stone quarries, and built the royal monuments." Slaves were people captured as prisoners of war, they were forced to work on building projects."Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. In addition to being forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles."
column4: The passage can be rewritten as follows:  "The pharaoh held supreme authority, governing all aspects of the Egyptian government. He was considered a god in human form, with immense power and influence. The pharaoh appointed a vizier to oversee taxes, ensuring their collection. He also appointed a chief minister, the vizier, responsible for collecting taxes effectively. The nobility held significant positions, profiting from tributes paid to the pharaoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods, performing rituals and ensuring divine favor. Below the nobility were soldiers, responsible for defending the country through war and domestic uprisings. These soldiers also oversaw the people, ensuring the safety and well-being of all citizens. At the lowest level were the slaves and farmers. Farmers tended the fields, raising animals, maintaining canals and reservoirs, and constructing stone monuments. Their hard work ensured the sustainability of agriculture, contributing to the wealth and prosperity of Egypt. Their dedication symbolized the value placed on the resources and workforce of the nation."

column3: The ways that the factories would use or cover up the spoiled meat was by mixing the spoiled with the good raw and selling it either way.  Another way would be to pump into the packer a much stronger pickle, which would destroy the odor of the spoiled and nobody would notice. "To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickly which destroyed the odor-a process known to the workers as "giving them thirty per cent".
column4: The methods used to conceal the spoiled meat were deceitful and manipulative. They involved mixing the spoiled meat with good quality raw meat and selling it as if it were the real deal. Another tactic involved infusing a pickle with a strong odor. The workers were aware of this practice and referred to it as "giving the meat 30 per cent."

column3: The first element of ideal tragedy is that it revolves around a single plot. There must not be too many issues presented to the audience as it would make it confusing. A second element shown by Aristotle is that the change of fortune should not have a quick turn from bad to good but that it should instead go from good to bad at the fault of some great error. For a true tragedy, the third element of having  a character go from good to bad is very important. This allows for true tragedy to take place that will leave the readers and audience shocked.
column4: Sure, here's the rewritten passage:   "A tragedy is characterized by a single central plot with few distractions. The character's journey from good to bad should be gradual and have a clear cause and effect. The presence of a single, significant, error is crucial to create a sense of dramatic consequence and ensure that the audience is both shocked and intrigued. Each element plays a part in creating a tragic narrative, which can leave the reader and audience captivated and eager to see how it unfolds."

column3: In those days they wanted to use meat as much as they could so in a factory they came up with different ways to use the spoiled meat .The factory would use every part of the pig except the squel . As stated in the text " whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage."(Sinclair.2)Another method was pickiling they used this on ham , this was a faster way to preserve the ham as stated " In the pickling of hams they had an ingenious apparatus," (Sinclair.2).They would use the meat to as much as there potential in order to save enough of that meat so it can be eaten again .
column4: In those days, there was a desire to maximize the utilization of meat, leading manufacturers to explore diverse ways to employ spoiled meat. One method involved the systematic removal of the squel from pig parts, as mentioned in the text. Another approach was pickling, which facilitated the preservation of hams by removing and preserving certain components. Through these methods, manufacturers could extract the maximum value from spoiled meat while preserving it for future consumption.
